email.title: Reading Groups Kick-Off Next Monday!
email.text:
Are you interested in learning more about research in academia? Are you looking for project ideas in the area of Computer Science?
If you're the inquisitive type, come along to our first Reading Groups of the year next **Monday the 28th of October**! Reading Groups are targeted at higher year students (postgraduates especially) who are interested in the kind of research that happens in Computer Science.
For more details take a look at the event information below and RSVP on Facebook!
email.heading: Reading Groups by Nuri Cingillioglu and Dr. Antoine Cully

event.text:
We are happy to announce that the Reading Groups are back! Reading Groups are lectures/panels where researchers talk about their current work, aimed at final and penultimate year undergraduate, as well as and postgraduate students. Our main goal for organising such talks is to expose students to different types of research in Computer Science. Our first 2 Reading Groups will be by Nuri Cingillioglu and Dr. Antoine Cully.
Reading Group by Dr. Antoine Cully 1 - 1.30pm
Title: Creative Learning algorithms for Resilient Robots
Abstract: Reinforcement learning algorithms are tightly linked with the optimisation of functions to find the best solution according to one or several objectives. Recently, we developed a new family of optimisation algorithms, named Quality-Diversity optimisation, that contrasts with classic algorithms. Instead of searching for a single solution, Quality-Diversity algorithms are searching for a large collection of both diverse and high-performing solutions. With this approach, robots are capable of finding creative solutions to overcome complicated situations, like loss of a leg. During this seminar, I will show several examples of applications of these algorithms.
Reading Group by Nuri Cingillioglu 1.30 - 2pm
Title: Computational Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning and how machines can learn elements of logical thinking
Abstract: "Can machines think?" - asked Alan Turing in his 1950 seminal paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence". Recent advances in deep learning are yielding great results across practical applications such as natural language processing, image recognition and reinforcement learning; however, how machines can incorporate elements of logical thought and learn to reason are open to research. Combining machine learning with logic-based expert systems in order to get the best of both worlds are becoming increasingly more popular. In this talk, Iâ€™ll give a brief overview of my involvement in the field of neuro-symbolic reasoning and discuss how the future of Artificial Thought is evolving.
